For any seminormed additive commutative group E, subset s, and real number Œ¥, the set {x : E | ‚à•x‚à• ‚â§ Œ¥ ‚à® x ‚àà s} equals the set {x : E | ‚à•x - o ‚à• ‚â§ Œ¥}, where o is the origin of E.

The theorem `Int.gcd_dvd_left` states that for any two integers `a` and `b`, the greatest common divisor (gcd) of `a` and `b` divides `a`. This is written in the Lean theorem prover as `‚Üë(Int.gcd a b) ‚à£ a`, where `Int.gcd a b` computes the gcd of `a` and `b`, the `‚Üë` operator converts that gcd from a natural number to an integer, and `‚à£` represents the "divides" relation. In mathematical terms, if $gcd(a, b) = d$, then $d | a$.

type: ‚àÄ {a b : ‚Ñ§}, ‚Üë(a.gcd b) ‚à£ a
name: Int.gcd_dvd_left
docString: The theorem `Int.gcd_dvd_left` states that for any two integers `a` and `b`, the greatest common divisor (gcd) of `a` and `b` divides `a`. This is written in the Lean theorem prover as `‚Üë(Int.gcd a b) ‚à£ a`, where `Int.gcd a b` computes the gcd of `a` and `b`, the `‚Üë` operator converts that gcd from a natural number to an integer, and `‚à£` represents the "divides" relation. In mathematical terms, if $gcd(a, b) = d$, then $d | a$.

In a Euclidean domain with decidable equality, the greatest common divisor of any two elements divides the first element.

type: ‚àÄ {R : Type u} [inst : EuclideanDomain R] [inst_1 : DecidableEq R] (a b : R), EuclideanDomain.gcd a b ‚à£ a
name: EuclideanDomain.gcd_dvd_left
docString: In a Euclidean domain with decidable equality, the greatest common divisor of any two elements divides the first element.

The theorem `Nat.gcd_dvd` states that for all natural numbers `m` and `n`, the greatest common divisor (GCD) of `m` and `n` is a divisor of both `m` and `n`. In other words, the GCD of two numbers divides each of the two numbers. This is a fundamental property of the GCD, typically denoted mathematically as $\text{gcd}(m, n) | m$ and $\text{gcd}(m, n) | n$.

type: ‚àÄ (m n : ‚Ñï), m.gcd n ‚à£ m ‚àß m.gcd n ‚à£ n
name: Nat.gcd_dvd
docString: The theorem `Nat.gcd_dvd` states that for all natural numbers `m` and `n`, the greatest common divisor (GCD) of `m` and `n` is a divisor of both `m` and `n`. In other words, the GCD of two numbers divides each of the two numbers. This is a fundamental property of the GCD, typically denoted mathematically as $\text{gcd}(m, n) | m$ and $\text{gcd}(m, n) | n$.
